text: A high AERIAL SHOT of the island features the Statue of L prominently in the foreground then TRAVELS ACROSS the har Battery and Lower Manhattan to Greenwich Village.

A car is being hoisted up by a municipal tow truck while having a terrible screaming arguement with a parking enfo DANA BARRETT comes home pushing a baby buggy, struggling bags of groceries, and trying to dig her keys out of her building superintendent FRANK, sees her struggling but pr notice.
(exasperated) Frank, do you think you could give me a hand with these bags?
I'm not a doorman, Miss Barrett.  I'm a building superintendent.
You're also a human being, Frank.
(reluctantly going to help) Okay, okay.  It's not my job, but what the hell.  I'll do you a favor.  He takes the grocery bags from her.
(setting the wheel brakes on the buggy) Thank you, Frank.  I'll get the hang of this eventually.
She continues digging in her purse while Frank leans over makes funny faces at the baby, OSCAR, a very cute nine-mo
(to the baby) Hiya, Oscar.  What do you say, slugger?
(to Dana) That's a good-looking kid you got there, Ms. Barrett.
(finding her keys) Thank you, Frank.  Oh, are you ever going to fix the radiator in my bedroom?  I asked you last week.
Didn't I do it?
It starts to vibrate as if shaken by an unseen hand.
He GURGLES with delight at the movement.
Neither of them notice the movement of the carriage.
No, you didn't, Frank.
Okay, that's no problem.
That's exactly what you said last week.
The brakes unlock themselves.

She reaches for the handlebar of the buggy, but the buggy just out of her reach and stops.  Surprised by the moveme for the handlebar again, but this time the buggy rolls aw further.  Alarmed now, Dana hurries after it, but the bug rolling down the street at ever increasing speed.
Dana chases the buggy down the street, shouting to passin for help, but every time someone reaches out to stop it, swerves and continues unchecked.
Cars, trucks, and buses speed by in both directions as th toward the corner.
She puts her head down and sprints after the buggy like a
A city bus is on a collision course with the speeding bab
It careens toward the corner.
Its eyes are wide open with excitement.
Bus and buggy are closing fast as the buggy bounces over into the crosswalk.
The bus driver reacts in helpless horror as he sees the b intersection at high speed.
It comes to a dead stop right in the middle of the street continues missing the buggy by inches.

Cars and trucks swerve and hit their brakes as Dana runs intersection and snatches up the baby.  She hugs it close relieved, then looks at the buggy with the dawning awaren supernatural has re-entered her life.

THEME MUSIC kicks in strongly as we see the familiar "No and PULL BACK to reveal that it's painted on the side of Ghostbusters' emergency vehicle, which is speeding up Bro Upper West Side.  RAY STANTZ is driving and WINSTON ZEDDE shotgun.
The Ectomobile pulls up in front of a carefully-restored Stantz and Winston, wearing their official Ghostbuster un out of the old ambulance, shoulder their proton packs and house.
A WOMAN greets them and leads them through the expensivel house.
(all business) How many of them are there, ma'am?
Fourteen.  They're in the back.  I hope you can handle them.  It's been like a nightmare.
How big are they?
She holds her hand out indicating about four feet.
(resolute) We'll do our best, ma'am.
They're right out here.
She leads them to a set of French doors that open into an Stantz and Winston pause to make final adjustments to the
Ready?
I'm ready.
Then let's do it.
He pushes through the French doors and they step into the
They are immediately attacked by fourteen or fifteen scre between the ages of seven and ten.
(disappointed) Ghostbusters!!  Boooo!!
Tables are set with party favors, ice cream and birthday room is strewn with discarded toys and games.  A couple o sink onto lawn chairs as Stantz and Winston take over the
(trying his best) How you doin', kids?
(nasty) I though we were having He-Man.
He-Man couldn't make it today.  That's why we're here.
My dad says you're full of crap.
(stopped cold) Well, a lot of people have trouble believing in the paranormal.
No, he just says you're full of crap and that's why you went out of business.
He kicks Stantz in the leg.  Stantz grabs him by the shir
(low and menacing) I'm watching you. (to Winston) Song.
Winston switches on a tiny TAPE RECORDER which starts PLA Ghostbusters THEME SONG. Stantz and WInston start singing
'There's something wrong in the neighborhood. Who you gonna call?'
(all together) He-Man!!
Stantz and Winston wearily load their equipment into the
That's it, Ray.  I've had it.  No more parties. I'm tired of taking abuse from over-privileged nine-year-olds.
Come on, Winston.  We can't quit now.  The holidays are coming up.  It's our best season.
They get in the car
Stantz tries to start the car, but the engine won't turn
Give it up, Ray.  You're living in the past. Ghostbusters doesn't exist anymore.  In a year these kids won't even remember who we are.
(tries to start the car again) Ungrateful little Yuppie larvae.  After all we did for this city.
Yeah, what did we do, Ray?  The last real job we had we bubbled up a hundred foot marshmallow man and blew the top three floors off an uptown highrise.
Yeah, but what a ride.  You can't make a hamburger without chopping up a cow.

He turns the key again, the ENGING TURNS OVER, then start CLUNKING disastrously, chewing up vital parts and droppin of metal onto the pavement.  Finally, with a BLAST of bla exhaust from the tailpipe, Ecto-1 shudders and dies.  Fru bangs his head lightly on the steering wheel

A bank of monitors in the lobby show the program now runn Channel 10 in New York. We PUSH IN ON one of the monitors card and logo come up accompanied by some EERIE SYNTHESIZ we return to the show in progress: "World of the Psychic Venkman."  There is a video dissolve to a standard talk s sitting there is our host PETER VENKMAN, the renowned and infamous ex-Ghostbuster.
He turns TO CAMERA and talks to his viewers in a suavely understated and intimate.

Hi, welcome back to the 'World of the Psychic,' I'm Peter Venkman and I'm chatting with my guest, author, lecturer and of course, psychic, Milton Anglund. (to his guest) Milt, your new book is called The End of the World.  Isn't that kind of like writing about gum disease.  Yes, it could happen, but do you think anybody wants to read a book about it?
Well, I think it's important for people to know that the world is in danger.
Okay, so can you tell us when it's going to happen or do we have to buy the book?
I predict that the world will end at the stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve.

This year?  That's cutting it a little close, isn't it?  I mean, just from a sales point of view, the book just came out, right?  So you're not even looking at the paperback release for maybe a year.  And it's going to be at least another year after that if the thing has movie-of-the-week or mini-series potential. You would have been better off predicting 1992 or even '94 just to be safe.
(irritated) This is not just some money-making scheme!  I didn't just make up the date.  I have a strong psychic belief that the world will end on New Year's Eve.
(placating) Well, for your sake, I hope you're right.  But I think my other guest may disagree with you. Elaine, you had another date in mind?
The CAMERA REVEALS ELAINE, an attractive, aggressive New housewife, sitting on the other side of Venkman.
According to my sources, the world will end on February 14, in the year 2016.
Valentine's Day.  That's got to be a bummer. Where did you get that date, Elaine?

I received this information from an alien.  I was at the Paramus Holiday Inn, I was having a drink in the bar when he approached me and started talking.  Then he must have used some sort of ray or a mind control device because he made me follow him to his room and that's where he told me about the end of the world.
Your alien had a room in the Holiday Inn?
It may have been a room on the spacecraft made up to look like a room in the Holiday Inn.  I can't be sure, Peter.

(humoring her) No, you can't, and I think that's the whole problem with aliens; you just can't trust them. You may get some nice ones occasionally like Starman or E.T., but most of them turn out to be some kind of lizard.  Anyway, we're just about out of time. (does his wrap-up right TO the CAMERA) Next week on 'World of the Psychic,' hairless pets. (holds up a hairless cat) Until then, this is Peter Venkman saying ... (puts a finger to his temple and sends out a though to his viewers) ... Good night.
Venkman comes out of the studio squabbling with his produ well-meaning young incompetent.
Where do you find these people?  I thought we were having the telekinetic guy who bends the spoons?
A lot of the better psychics won't come on the show.  They think you're too skeptical.
Skeptical!  Norman, I'm a pushover.  I think professional wrestling is real.
There is a small commotion down the hall as two plainclot out of the next studio followed by a group of mayoral ass
(to Norman) What's all this?
They just interviewed the mayor on 'Cityline.'
The Mayor!  He's a friend of mine.
Venkman starts down the hall as the MAYOR and his princip HARDEMEYER, come walking out of the studio.
(calling to the Mayor) Lenny!
The Mayor sees Venkman, blanches and hurries off, pretend him.
(starts to follow him) Lenny!  It's Pete Venkman!
The plainclothesmen cut Venkman off and Hardemeyer puts a against Venkman's chest.
(snide) Can I help you?
(dangerous) Yeah, you can get your hand off my chest.
Hardemeyer smiles and drops his hand.
I'm Jack Hardemeyer.  I'm the mayor's assistant. What can I do for you?
I'm an old friend of the mayor's.  I just want to say hello to him.
(scornful) I know who you are, Doctor Venkman.  Busting any ghosts lately?
No, that's what I want to talk to the mayor about.  We did a little job for the city a while back and we ended up getting sued, screwed and tattooed by deskworms like you.

(bristling) Look, you stay away from the mayor.  Next fall, barring a disaster, he's going to be elected governor of this state and the last thing we need is for him to be associated with two-bit frauds and publicity hounds like you and your friends.  You read me?
Hardemeyer walks off with the two cops.
Okay, I get it.  But I want you to tell Lenny that, because of you, I'm not voting for him.
The broad front steps of the museum are crowded with tour visitors.  Dana arrives carrying a portfolio and artist's enters the museum.

We are FULL-FRAME ON a larger-than-life, full-figure port THE CARPATHIAN, a demented and sadistic 16th century desp incredibly powerful evil presence.  Then we PULL BACK to studio, which is a large open space on the top floor of t by large skylights in the ceiling.  Working on the Vigo p JANOSZ POHA, a youngish art historian and painter, the he department, quirky, intense and somewhat creepy.  Janosz longingly across the room at Dana.
She is carefully cleaning a 19th Century landscape painti preoccupied by the extraordinary near-accident with the b watches her for a moment, then comes up behind her and lo shoulder.
(with an East European accent) Still working on the Turner?
Dana jumps, startled by the intrusion.
Oh, yes, I got in a little late this morning, Janosz.
You know, you are really doing very good work here.  I think soon you may be ready to assist me in some of the more important restorations.
Thank you, Janosz.  I've learned a lot here, but now that my baby's a little older, I was hoping to rejoin the orchestra.
At the mention of Dana's baby, the figure of Vigo miracul head and looks at Dana.
Neither of them notice the movement in the painting.
(disappointed) We'll be very sorry to lose you.  Perhaps I could take you to lunch today?
Actually, I'm not eating lunch today.  I have an appointment. (looks at her watch) In fact, I'd better go.
She starts gathering up her things.
Every day I ask you, and every day you've got something else to do.  Do I have bad breath or something?
(trying to brush him off) I'm sorry.  Perhaps some other time.
Okay, I'll take a raincheck on that.
Janosz smiles at her as she exits, then goes back to his
(to himself) I think she likes me.
He switches on an English language TAPE and starts practi phrases as he resumes working.
Dana Barrett crosses the quad and enters a modern buildin identifies it as "The Institute for Advanced Theoretical

Dana is explaining the buggy incident to EGON SPENGLER, t intellectual techno-wizard and former Ghostbuster, as he experiment assisted by a research team of graduate studen are Japanese, Chinese, or Korean.  The device he is testi box about the size of a Sony Watchman with both digital a displays.
... and then the buggy just suddenly stopped dead in the middle of the street
Did anyone else see this happen?
Hundreds of people.  Believe me, I didn't imagine this.
I'm not saying you did.  In science we always look for the simplest explanation.
An ASSISTANT interrupts.
We're ready, Dr. Spengler
(to the Assistant) We'll start with the negative calibration.
He picks up the device and prepares to test it.
(curious) What are you working on, Egon?
I'm trying to determine whether human emotional states have a measurable effect on the psychomagnetheric energy field.  It's a theory Ray and I were working on when we had to dissolve Ghostbusters.
An assistant draws a curtain revealing a large picture wi a two-way mirror, that looks into a small waiting room. waiting room they can see but not hear a youngish couple arguement.

(to Dana) They think they're here for marriage counseling.  We've kept them waiting for two hours and we've been gradually increasing the temperature in the room. (checking a heat sensor) It's up to 95 degrees at the moment.  Now my assistant is going to enter and ask them if they'd mind waiting another half-hour.

As Spengler, Dana, and the research team watch, the assis waiting room and tells the couple about the new delay.  T with anger both at him and each other while Spengler moni through the glass.  After recording his readings, he retu Assistant.
We'll do the happiness index next. (to Dana) I'd like to bring Ray in on your case, if it's all right with you.
Okay, whatever you think -- but not Venkman.
Oh no.
(affectedly casual) Do you ever see him?
Occasionally
How is he these days?
Venkman?  I think he was borderline for a while there.  Then he crossed the border.
Does he ever mention me?
No.  Not that I can recall.
They move to another two-way mirror through which they ca little girl playing with a wonderful array of toys.
(slightly disappointed) Well, we didn't part on very good terms and we sort of lost track of each other when I got married.
The Assistant interrupts again.
We're ready for the affection test.
(to the assistant) Good.  Send in the puppy.
(continuing) I thought of calling him after my marriage ended, but --.  Anyway, I appreciate you're doing this, Egon
They watch as another assistant enters the playroom with Cocker Spaniel puppy and gives it to the little girl.  Sp her as she jumps for joy and hugs the little dog.
(handing him a card) This is my address and telephone number. Will you call me?
Certainly.
Egon, I'd rather you didn't mention any of this to Peter if you don't mind.
I won't.
Thank you.
She shakes his hand and exits.
(to his assistant) Now let's see how she reacts when we take away the puppy
It's a small basement shop located on a quaint commercial Greenwich Village.  The window is crowded with occult art books full of arcane metaphysical lore.  The TELEPHONE RI
(v.o., answering the phone) Ray's Occult.

The shelves are jammed floor to ceiling with books on the Ray sits on a barstool behind the counter wearing an old sweater over a T-shirt.  He has on a pair of reading glas on a battered, reeking pipe.  As he talks on the phone he of herb tea for Spengler who is thumbing through an arcan

(on the phone) Yeah ... mmhmm ... What do you need? ... What have I got?  I've got alchemy, astrology, apparitions, Bundu Magic Men, demon intercession, U.F.O. abductions, psychic surgery, stigmata, modern miracles, pixie sightings, golden geese, geists, ghosts, I've got it all -- what are you looking for? ... Don't have any.  Try the stockyards.
He hangs up.
Who was that?
Some crank.  Looking for goat hooves.  Come up with anything?
(referring to the book) This one's interesting.  Berlin, 1939, a flower cart took off by itself and rolled approximately half a kilometer over level ground.  Three hundred eyewitnesses.
You might want to check those Duke University mean averaging studies on controlled psychokinesis.
(going to the stacks) Good idea.
The bones hanging over the door rattle as Venkman enters
Oh, hello, perhaps you could help me.  I'm looking for an aerosol love potion I could spray on a certain Penthouse Pet that would make her unconditionally submit to an unusual personal request.
Oh, hiya, Pete.
So, no goat hooves, huh?
(strung) I knew that voice sounded familiar.  What's up?  How's it going?
Nowhere -- fast.  Why don't you lock up and buy me a sub?
(slightly evasive) Uh, I can't.  I'm kind of working on something.
Spengler steps out of the stacks.
Egon!
Hello, Venkman.
How've you been?  How's teaching?  I bet those science chicks really dig that big cranium of yours, huh?
I think they're more interested in my epididymis.
I don't even want to know where that is.
Venkman steps behind the counter and takes a beer from Ra
Oh, your book came in, Venkman.  Magical Paths to Fortune and Power.
He hands Venkman the book.
Great. (reading the contents) So what are you guys working on?
Oh, just checking something for an old friend.
Who?
(at a loss) Who?  Just -- someone we know.
Oh, Ray --
He grabs Stantz by both ears and pulls up.
Who?  Who?  Who?
Aaah!  Nobody!  I can't tell you!
Who, Ray?
(giving in) Dana!  Dana Barrett!
Venkman lets go of his ears and smiles.  Spengler looks a shakes his head.
The apartment is old and creatively furnished with a comf modern and traditional pieces.  Maria, a young Hispanic w day care for Dana, is feeding the baby in the kitchen whe RINGS.
Dana enters from the bedroom and crosses to the front doo it and admits Ray and Egon.
(hugging Ray) Hi, Ray.  It's good to see you.  Thanks for coming.
No problem.  Always glad to help -- and hug.
(to Spengler) Hi, Egon.
She shakes his hand and is about to close the door when V in the doorway.
Hi, Dana.
Dana is caught completely off guard by Venkman's surprise
I knew you'd come crawling back to me.
She regards him coolly, as always amused and amazed at hi presumptuousness.
Hello, Peter.
(to Dana) You know, Dana, I'm very very hurt that you didn't call me first.  I'm still into all this stuff, you know.  Haven't you ever seen my show?
I have.  That's why I didn't call you first.
I can see that you're still very bitter about us, but in the interest of science, I'm going to give it my best shot.  Let's go to work, boys.
Stantz and Spengler begin a comprehensive parapsychologic the baby and the immediate physical environment.
Venkman starts nosing around the apartment.  Dana follows
So what happened to Mr. Right?  I hear he ditched you and the kid and moved to Europe.
He didn't "ditch" me.  We had some problems, he got a good offer from an orchestra in England and he took it.
He ditched you.  You should've married me, you know.
You never asked me, and every time I brought it up you'd get drowsy and fall asleep.
Men are very sensitive, you know.  We need to feel loved and desired, too.
Well, when you started introducing me as "the old ball and chain," that's when I left.
I may have a few personal problems but one thing I am is a total professional.
He leaves her and crosses to Spengler.
He's taking a complete set of body and head measurements with a tape measure and calipers.
What are you going to do, Egon?  Knit him a snowsuit?
Spengler ignores the remark and hands Venkman a specimen
I'd like to have a stool specimen
Yeah, you would.  Is that for personal or professional reasons?
(picking up the baby) Okay, kid.  Up you go.
He starts clowning with the baby, holding him over his he his nose into the baby's belly, pretending that the baby him.
Help!  Please somebody help me!  Get him off! Quickly!  He's gone completely berserk!
Dana is amused and somewhat disarmed by Venkman's rapport
What do you think?

There's no doubt about it.  He's got his father's looks.  The kid is ugly -- extremely ugly.  And smelly. (resumes playing with the baby) You stink!  It's just horrible.  You are the stinkiest baby I ever smelled. (to Dana) What's his name?
His name is Oscar.
Oscar!  You poor kid!
(losing patience) Peter, this is serious.  I need to know if you think there's anything unusual about him.
Unusual? (holds up the baby and scrutinizes him) I don't know.  I haven't had a lot of experience with babies.
He looks at the baby, pulling his feet up, trying to get off.
(taking the specimen jar) I'll do it.
I'll supervise.
Venkman enters and finds Stantz monitoring the room.
(to Stantz) Well, Holmes, what do you think?
It's an interesting one, Pete.  If anything was going on it's totally subdued now.
Spengler enters.
(to Spengler) What now, Brainiac?
I think we should see if we can find anything abnormal on the street.
Finding something abnormal on the street shouldn't be too hard.
Dana walks down the street with Venkman, retracing the pa runaway buggy.  Spengler and Stantz follow, monitoring PK the pavement and the buildings.

(to Dana, nostalgic) Brings back a lot of sweet memories, doesn't it? (pointing out familiar neighborhood sights) There's our old cash machine.  And the dry cleaners we used to go to.  And the old video store. (he wipes away an imaginary tear) We really had some good times, didn't we?
We definitely had a moment or two.
Dana stops at the intersection and points to the middle o
That's where the buggy stopped.
Okay, let's take a look.

Venkman walks right out into the middle of the street, co oblivious to the CARS HONKING and whizzing past him and s like a traffic cop, bringing traffic to a standstill.  Th for Dana, Stantz and Spengler to join him in the middle o
(reading the PKE meter) Is this the spot?
A little to the left.  Right there!  That's where it stopped.
Stantz reads the PKE meter.
Nothing.  Not a trace.
Why don't we try the Giga-meter?
What's that?
Egon and I have been working on a gauge to measure psychomagnetheric energy in GEVs - giga electron volts.
That's a thousand million electron volts.
I knew that.
Spengler switches on the Giga-meter, the device he was te lab, and passes it over the spot on the street where the The indicator goes right into the red zone and the DEVICE WILDLY.
I think we hit the honeypot, boys.  There's something brewing under the street.
(worried, to Venkman) Peter, do you think maybe I have some genetic problem or something that makes me vulnerable to these supernatural things.
You mean like the time you got possessed and turned into a monster terror dog?  No, not a chance.  Total coincidence. (to Stantz and Spengler) Am I right?
Stantz and Spengler look at him skeptically, not convince coincidence theory.
The museum has just closed for the day and the last of th employees are leaving.
Janosz is working late on the painting of Vigo.
Unnoticed by Janosz, the eyes of Vigo start to glow.
He touches his brush to the canvas and a powerful current crackling energy surges through the brush and courses thr driving him to his knees.
The figure of Vigo comes to life, turns toward Janosz and dramatically at him.  Then he speaks to Janosz in a comma
I, Vigo, the scourge of Carpathia, the sorrow of Moldavia, command you.
(in agony) Command me, lord.
On a mountain of skulls in a castle of pain, I sat on a throne of blood.  What was will be, what is will be no more.  Now is the season of evil.  Find me a child that I might live again.
Bolts of red-hot energy shoot from the eyes of Vigo into He screams and falls to his knees.
Venkman and Stantz come out with small boxes containing c sandwiches and Danish and start walking up the street.
I love this.  We're onto something really big.  I can smell it, Ray.  We're going to make some headlines with this one.
Hey, hey, hey, stresshound!  Are you nuts? If anybody found out about this we'd be in serious trouble.  The judge couldn't have been clearer - no ghostbusting.
Relax.  We're going to keep this whole thing nice and quiet, low key, no profile.
Spengler, wearing a hardhat, is JACKHAMMERING a hole in t street.  Safety cones and reflectors have been set up and lit by strong work lights.

It turns onto East 77th Street, cruises slowly up to the worksite and stops.  The noise of the JACKHAMMER is so lo doesn't notice the police car and the two COPS inside loo Finally, he looks up, sees the police car and freezes.
How ya doing?
(reeking with guilt) Fine!  It's cutting fine now.
(curious) Why are you cutting?
(looking for one of the others) Why are we cutting?  Uh - boss!
Venkman and Stantz arrive just in time wearing Con Ed har good imitation of a Consolidated Edison repairman.
What are you doing here?

(belligerent) What the hell's it look like we're doing? We're bustin out asses over here 'cause some douchebag downtown ain't got nothin' better to do than make idiots like us work late on a Friday night, right? (looks to Spengler for agreement)
(with a "right on" fist) Yo.
The cops seem satisfied by the explanation.
Okay, boys, take it easy.
They drive off.  Spengler breathes a great sigh of relief rubbing his sore shoulders.
You were supposed to help me with this.
You need the exercise.

Stantz resumes JACKHAMMERING, while Venkman and Spengler rubble from the hole.  Suddenly he hits metal.  They clea generations of paving material revealing an ornate iron m The manhole cover bears a strange logo and the letters NY
(examing it) NYPRR.  What the hell -- ?  Help me lift this.
They prey off the iron cover with crowbars, uncovering a very deep abyss.
(shining a flashlight into the hole) Wow!  It's an old airshaft.  It just goes forever.
Spengler leans in with the giga-meter which is reading ev
Very intense.  We need a deeper reading. Somebody has to go down there.
Venkman and Spengler both look at Ray.
Thanks, boys.
They snap Stantz into a harness and lower him into the ho cable attached to a winch.  Ray calls out orders to them deeper and deeper.
(his voice echoing in the airshaft) Keep going -- more -- more --
Stantz rappels off the sides of the airshaft as he contin in total darkness.
(using a radio now) Lower -- lower -- (to himself) Gee, this really is deep.
Suddenly, his feet kick thin air as he gets to the bottom and swings free in some kind of tunnel.
(shouts) Hold it!  Steady!
He pulls a powerful flashlight from his utility belt and the tunnel below.
He is suspended near the top of a beautifully preserved c rounded, polished tile walls ardorned with intricate, col Art Nouveau mosaics.  A finely inlaid sign identifies it STATION.
He pans the walls with his flashlight, admiring the excel and speaks quietly to Venkman and Spengler over his walki
(reverently) This is it, boys, the end of the line.  Van Horne Station.  The old New York Pneumatic. It's still here.
Venkman has no idea what he's talking about.
(explaining) The New York Pneumatic Railway.  It was an experimental subway system.  Fan-forced air-trains, built around 1870.
(over the walkie-talkie) This is about as deep as you can go under Manhattan without digging your own hole.
(to Stantz) What's the reading?
Stantz shines his flashlight on the meter and whistles at high reading.
(on the radio) Off the top of the scale.  This place is really hot.  Lower me to the floor.
As Venkman and Spengler feed him some more cable, he pans down the wall of the station, then onto the floor.
(shouts) Hold it!!  Stop!!  Whoa!!

Below him is a river of bubbling seething, glowing slime, torrent of disgusting ooze. As he stares into the foul effluent, we become aware of t amplified and magnified sounds of great ENGINES THROBBING the bowels of the city, of WATER RUSHING through pipes, S through ducts, the muffled RUMBLE of the SUBWAY and the R and mixed with it all, the unmistakable sounds of human c -- VOICES SHOUTING in anger, SCREAMING in fear, GROANING and eerie symphony.
(ranting on the radio) Oh, my God!  It's a seething, bubbling, psychic cess!  Interlocked tubes of plasm, crackling with negative GEVs!  It's glowing and moving!  It's -- it's a river of slime!!

He dangles from the end of the cable, holding his feet up can.  He unhooks a device from his utility belt and pulls it, shooting out a long telescoping fishing-pole with a s Reaching down, he scoops up a sample of the slime and sta the pole.
